column4: /proc/cpuinfo is showing a 1.0 Ghz processor when im running a 2.4 Ghz processor, how can i resolve this?
right click your panel, click "add to panel", and add the "cpu frequency scaling monitor" if you want to keep an eye on the scaling
actually i need to read processor statistics from a script. so no GUI
the info you are looking for is also in /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/cpuinfo_max_freq
thanks :)
im assuming its cpu1, cpu2, etc for multiple cores?
correct; I'd just change directory to /sys/devices/system/cpu and start looking around; all the info you ever imagined should be at your fingertips ;)
thank you :)
first take a look at /proc/net/dev for basic counters
thank you
useful counters but i need to know the current kb/sec (or mb) upload and download in use, not the total
you can calculate that by diffing the totals over time...
i could continually read that file, but i was hoping a tool was already made
i could, what about the connection speed (to the router not to the net)
for that, you can run "ethtool eth0" (unfortunately requires root, not sure if there is another tool available that doesn't)
i can subprocess and grant just that command root and leave the application unprivileged :) thanks again
you assumed correctly, thanks for your help. i never run scripts as root if i can help it :)
almost forgot; another really useful command is "nm-tool" (but it won't work if network manager is not being used)
thanks
network manager is being used in this case, but we will probably move to very very minimal debian installs in the near future
you might be able to get some of that info by running 'sudo dmidecode'
you are a command and log file encyclopedia :)
